hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ali (may Allah be pleased with him): He said: 'When you enter a city and have decided to stay for ten days, then complete (the full prayer)'. Zaid ibn Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) also said: 'Do not shorten the prayer except for a journey of three days. When you leave your house intending to travel for three days or more, shorten when you pass beyond the houses of your people and city'. Also narrated: The Prophet ﷺ prayed two rak'ahs and two rak'ahs in Makkah until he returned. Also narrated: The Prophet ﷺ used to perform optional prayer on his camel during his travel, wherever his camel turned, making signs with his head, making his prostration lower than his bowing. He did not perform obligatory prayers or Witr except when he alighted. Zaid ibn Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) also said: When a resident enters the prayer of a traveler and the traveler says the greeting, the resident stands and completes (the full prayer). When a traveler enters the prayer of a resident, he prays with his (the resident's) prayer'

Topics: Obligatory prostration verses in the Quran

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ali (may Allah be pleased with him): He said: 'The obligatory prostrations in the Quran are four: Alif Lam Meem (Chapter 2), and Ha Meem (Chapter 41), and An-Najm (Chapter 53), and Iqra' bismi rabbika alladi khalaq (Chapter 96). He also said: As for the rest of what is in the Quran, if you wish you may prostrate and if you wish you may leave it'. He was asked about a man who reads a prostration verse multiple times in a gathering. He said: One prostration suffices him. Zaid ibn Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) also said: If the prostration is at the end of the chapter, incorporate it in the ruku (bowing), and if it is in the middle of the chapter, there is no escaping from prostrating. He was asked about a man who hears the prostration verse from a dhimmi (non-Muslim under covenant), or a woman, or a child. He said: He prostrates'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ali (may Allah be pleased with him): When he would lead the people in eclipse prayer, he would begin by saying takbeer, then recite al-Hamd and a chapter from the Quran, reciting aloud at night or during the day, then perform ruku for about the length of what he recited, then raise his head from the ruku and say takbeer, continuing this five times. When he raised his head from the fifth ruku, he would say 'Sami' a-llahu liman hamidah' (Allah hears those who praise Him). When standing, he would not recite, then say takbeer and perform two prostrations. Then raise his head and do in the second rak'ah as he did in the first, saying takbeer whenever he raised his head from ruku in the four times, and saying 'Sami' a-llahu liman hamidah' on the fifth, and he would not recite after the fifth ruku

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ali (may Allah be pleased with him): He said: In the prayer of fear, the leader divides his companions into two groups. One group stands opposite the enemy and takes their weapons, and he prays with the group that is with him one rak'ah and two prostrations. When the leader raises his head from the second prostration, they should position themselves behind them, and another group who have not yet prayed should come to pray with him. The first group retreats and takes the position of their companions. He then prays with the second group one rak'ah and two prostrations, then gives the salam. The two groups then stand, the first group completes one rak'ah and two prostrations then gives salam. They then stand at the position of their companions, and those who were opposite the enemy come forward and pray one rak'ah and two prostrations and give salam
